rev.diff:
Line 97: Line 97:
In 1974 Crivitz was once again incorporated as the Village of Crivitz. This was quickly followed by improvements in the water-sewer system, electrical system, and highway-transportation system. The village currently operates under its 1974 incorporation with a Village President (executive), a Board of Trustees (legislative), and a Municipal Judge (judicial). Village operations are carried out by the Public Works Department, Water-Sewer Department, Police Department, Fire Department, and Parks Department.
In 1974 Crivitz was once again incorporated as the Village of Crivitz. This was quickly followed by improvements in the water-sewer system, electrical system, and highway-transportation system. The village currently operates under its 1974 incorporation with a Village President (executive), a Board of Trustees (legislative), and a Municipal Judge (judicial). Village operations are carried out by the Public Works Department, Water-Sewer Department, Police Department, Fire Department, and Parks Department.
â   â
On July 4, 2009, Crivitz cringed in the national spotlight as four municipal officers of repression (i.e., Crivitz Police) forcibly removed an upside down American flag from the private residence of a local Veteran, in anticipation of the pathetic local July 4 Parade, allegedly to celebrate "America's Freedom." The current mayor, John Deshane, while calling himself a veteran, renounced all rights to call himself an American, by claiming the subject of the Police Action should find "another way to protest." Officials at all levels admitted that no crime had been done as there is no law against flying a flag upside down. The Wisconsin Civil Liberties Union, in a rare agreement with freedom-loving Americans across the political spectrum (including hard-right conservatives), anticipate an aggressive suit against the Village of Crivitz, which may result in its disincorporation once again.
